Section: INCLUSION CRITERIA
Question: Suspected or confirmed mpox
Definition:
Refer to the case definitions of the World Health Organisation (WHO) or your local public health case definitions. 
The WHO define a confirmed case as: A person with laboratory confirmed mpox virus infection by detection of unique sequences of viral DNA by real-time polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and/or sequencing.
The WHO define a suspected case as: 
i. A person who is a contact of a probable or confirmed mpox case in the 21 days before the onset of signs or symptoms, and who presents with any of the following: acute onset of fever (>38.5°C), headache, myalgia (muscle pain/body aches), back pain, profound weakness or fatigue. 
OR
ii. A person presenting since 01 January 2022 with an unexplained acute skin rash, mucosal lesions orlymphadenopathy (swollen lymph nodes). The skin rash may include single or multiple lesions in the ano-genital region or elsewhere on the body. Mucosal lesions may include single or multiple oral, conjunctival, urethral, penile, vaginal, or ano-rectal lesions. Ano-rectal lesions can also manifest as ano-rectal inflammation (proctitis), pain and/or bleeding.
AND
for which the following common causes of acute rash or skin lesions do not fully explain the clinical picture: varicella zoster, herpes zoster, measles, herpes simplex, bacterial skin infections, disseminated gonococcus infection, primary or secondary syphilis, chancroid, lymphogranuloma venereum, granuloma inguinale, molluscum contagiosum, allergic reaction (e.g., to plants); and any other locally relevant common causes of papular or vesicular rash.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes' if the patient meets the case definitions for a suspected or confirmed mpox case.

Section: EXPOSURE HISTORY
Question: Eating bat/bird eaten fruits
Definition: Refers to the consumption of food contaminated by fluids from birds or bats.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes' if the patient reports to have consumed fruit contaminated by fluids from birds or bats in the 14 days prior to first symptom onset. If the patient is unsure, Indicate 'Unknown'.

Section: EXPOSURE HISTORY
Question: Close contact with patient with similar illness
Definition: Close contact refers to a patient who has provided care (including health care worker or family member) or had other similar close physical contact with a person exhibiting similar symptoms. It includes anyone who stayed at the same place (e.g. lived with, visited) as a person exhibiting similar symptoms. This close contact must have occured in the 14 days prior to first symptom onset for the participant.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes' if the patient has had close contact with a person exhibiting similar symptoms/illness in the 14 days prior to first symptom onset. If 'Yes' Specify below.

Section: EXPOSURE HISTORY
Question: Contact with bat/s
Definition: Refers to a patient who had direct physical contact or having been in close proximity with live/dead bat/s in the 14 days prior to first symptom onset. This can include being bitten by the specified animal; visiting an animal sanctuary or zoo housing the specified animal; and being involved in veterinary care, slaughtering or dissection of the specified animal.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes' if the patient has had exposure to bat/s in the 14 days prior to first symptom onset. If 'Yes' Specify below.

Section: EXPOSURE HISTORY
Question: Contact with pig/s
Definition: Refers to a patient who had direct physical contact or having been in close proximity with live/dead pig/s in the 14 days prior to first symptom onset. This can include being bitten by the specified animal; visiting an animal sanctuary or zoo housing the specified animal; and being involved in veterinary care, slaughtering or dissection of the specified animal.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes' if the patient has had exposure to pig/s in the 14 days prior to first symptom onset. If 'Yes' Specify below.

Section: EXPOSURE HISTORY
Question: Contact with domestic animal/s
Definition: Refers to a patient who had direct physical contact or having been in close proximity with a domesticated animal (e.g. cats and dogs) or other animals kept within the home. Contact must have occurred in the 14 days prior to first symptom onset.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes' if the patient has had exposure to domestic animals in the 14 days prior to first symptom onset. If 'Yes' Specify below.

Section: EXPOSURE HISTORY
Question: Other type of exposure history
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes' if there are other important exposures this patient has had in the 14 days prior to first symptom onset. If 'Yes' Specify below.

Section: PREGNANCY
Question: Pregnant
Definition: This refers to a women who is currently pregnant, confirmed by a pregnancy test.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient is pregnant. If the patient is of fertile age with no negative pregnancy test select 'Unknown'.

Section: PREGNANCY
Question: Gestational weeks assessment (weeks)
Definition: This refers to the gestational age of the foetus (written in weeks). It can be calculated from the woman's last menstrual period (LMP) or calculated using the best obstetrical estimated due date (EDD) based on the following formula: Gestational Age = (280 - (EDD - Reference Date)). The reference date is the date in which you are trying to determine the gestational age.
Completion Guideline: Indicate the gestational age of the foetus with the approximate numder of weeks.

Section: PREGNANCY
Question: Post-partum (within 6 weeks of delivery)
Definition: Defined as within six weeks of delivery.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient is in the post-partum period (within 6 weeks after delivery).

Question: Delivery date
Completion Guideline: Enter the date of delivery in day/month/year format.

Completion Guideline: Enter the gestational week of the child at the aforementioned pregnancy outcome.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to presentation or admission with this current illness and is ongoing (remains an active medical condition)
Question: Chronic cardiac disease (not hypertension)
Definition: Defined as a disease that progressively causes deterioration of the heart and its functioning. In some cases the direct cause of the disease may not be established. Some causes may include an infection that infiltrates the bloodstream that causes damage to the heart or having a genetic imperfection. These could involve: Congenital Heart Disease (haemodynamically significant) is defined as any structural or functional cardiac disorder that is present from birth which results in (1) need for medication to control congestive heart failure or (2) moderate to severe pulmonary hypertension, or (3) cyanotic heart disease. Excludes asymptomatic ventricular septal defects and patent ductus arteriosus e.g. those where no medication is required. Congestive heart disease is defined as any structural or functional cardiac disorder that impairs the ability of the ventricle to fill with or eject blood. It is characterized by specific symptoms, such as dyspnoea and fatigue, and signs, such as fluid retention. There are many ways to assess cardiac function. However, there is no diagnostic test for heart failure, since it is largely a clinical diagnosis that is based upon a careful history and physical examination.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission with this current illness and remains an active medical condition. Indicate 'No' if the patient does not have a history of this condition. Indicate 'Unknown' if it is not known whether the patient has a history of this condition or it is not ongoing.

Question: Hypertension (physician diagnosed)
Definition: Defined as elevated arterial blood pressure diagnosed clinically (systolic blood pressure >140mmHg systolic and/or diastolic blood pressure >90mmHg), or for which a patient is prescribed an anti-hypertensive.

Current pharmaceutical intervention - for prevention or treatment of symptoms - is not a pre-requisite for the inclusion of this diagnosis.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission with this current illness and remains an active medical condition. Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to presentation or admission with this current illness and is ongoing (remains an active medical condition)
Question: Chronic kidney disease
Definition: This is defined as a clinician-diagnosed chronic kidney disease (CKD, also known as chronic kidney failure). The KDIGO and KDOQI definition of chronic kidney disease is kidney damage for 3 months, as defined by structural or functional abnormalities of the kidney, with or without decreased glomerular filtration rate (GFR), that can lead to decreased GFR, manifest by either: Pathologic abnormalities; or Markers of kidney damage, including abnormalities in the composition of the blood or urine, or abnormalities in imaging tests; or GFR <60 mL/min/1.73 m^2 for 3 months, with or without kidney damage.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission with this current illness and remains an active medical condition. Indicate 'No' if the patient does not have a history of this condition. Indicate 'Unknown' if it is not known whether the patient has a history of this condition or it is not ongoing.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to presentation or admission with this current illness and is ongoing (remains an active medical condition)
Question: Obesity (as defined by clinical staff)
Definition: Defined as abnormal or excessive accumulation of fat or adipose tissue. This refers to patients for whom an attending clinician has assessed them to be obese - ideally but not necessarily with an objective measurement of obesity, such as calculation of the body mass index or measurement of abdominal girth. A body mass index (BMI) greater than or equal to 30 (kg/m2 or lbs/inch2) indicates obesity.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission with this current illness and remains an active medical condition. Indicate 'No' if the patient does not have a history of this condition. Indicate 'Unknown' if it is not known whether the patient has a history of this condition or it is not ongoing.

Question: Chronic neurological disorder

This includes disorders of the brain, spinal cord, cranial nerves, peripheral nerves, nerve roots, autonomic nervous system, neuromuscular junction, and muscle. This can include any of cerebral palsy, multiple sclerosis, motor neurone disease, muscular dystrophy, myasthenia gravis, Parkinson’s disease, stroke, and severe learning difficulty.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to presentation or admission with this current illness and is ongoing (remains an active medical condition)
Question: Malignant neoplasm
Definition: This refers to any known malignant neoplastic disease, including haematological malignancies, that is considered to be biologically active. A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. It specifically does not include malignancies that have been cured or where there is no evidence of on-going disease relating to that malignancy following treatment.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission with this current illness and remains an active medical condition. Indicate 'No' if the patient does not have a history of this condition. Indicate 'Unknown' if it is not known whether the patient has a history of this condition or it is not ongoing.

Do not include leukaemia, lymphoma or myeloma, which should be entered under malignancy. Do not include iron-deficiency anaemia which is explained by diet or chronic blood loss.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission with this current illness and remains an active medical condition. Question: eAG results within last 6 months (mmol/L)
Definition: Estimated average glucose (eAG) can be caculated from HbA1C or reported seperately in the units of mmol/L (similar to blood glucose levels). The relationship between HbA1C and eAG is described by: 28.7 × HbA1C – 46.7 = eAG.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to presentation or admission with this current illness and is ongoing (remains an active medical condition)
Question: Dementia
Definition: Defined as evidence from the history and mental status examination that indicates major impairment in learning and memory as well as at least one of the following: Impairment in handling complex tasks; Impairment in reasoning ability; Impaired spatial ability and orientation; Impaired language. The cognitive symptoms must significantly interfere with the individual's work performance, usual social activities, or relationships with other people. This must represent a significant decline from a previous level of functioning. The disturbances are of insidious onset and are progressive, based on evidence from the history or serial mental-status examinations. The disturbances are not occurring exclusively during the course of delirium. The disturbances are not better accounted for by a major psychiatric diagnosis. The disturbances are not better accounted for by a systemic disease or another brain disease. Chronic cognitive deficit is included.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission with this current illness and remains an active medical condition. Indicate 'No' if the patient does not have a history of this condition. Indicate 'Unknown' if it is not known whether the patient has a history of this condition or it is not ongoing.

Patients who have been cured of tuberculosis should not be included here. Those who have chronic pulmonary sequelae following their tuberculosis should be included as chronic pulmonary disease.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission with this current illness and remains an active medical condition. Indicate 'No' if the patient does not have a history of this condition. Indicate 'Unknown' if it is not known whether the patient has a history of this condition or it is not ongoing.

Question: Smoking
Answer Options: 1, Current smoker | 0, Never smoked | 3, Former smoker | 99, Unknown
Definition: This refers to smoking cigarettes, cigars, pipes or equivalent. Do not include smoke-free tobacco products such as chewed tobacco or electronic nicotine delivery devices. Current smoker is defined as  daily (smoking at least one of the above items per day) and non-daily smokers who has smoked 100 items in their life.Never smoker is defined as a person who has never smoked at the time of the assessment or has smoked less than 100 of the above items in their life. Former smoker is defined as a person who has quit smoking at the time of the assessment but has smoked at least 100 of the above items in their life.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to presentation or admission with this current illness and is ongoing (remains an active medical condition)
Question: History of severe organ failure or immunocompromise
Definition: This refers to the APACHE II definition of severe organ failure or immunocompromise. This includes: 1. Liver insufficiency: Biopsy proven cirrhosis; Documented portal hypertension; Episodes of past upper GI bleeding attributed to portal hypertension; prior episodes of hepatic. 2. Cardiovascular: New York Heart Association (NYHA) Class IV Heart Failure. 3. Respiratory: Chronic restrictive, or vascular disease resulting in severe exercise restriction, i.e. unable to climb stairs or perform household duties; Documented chronic hypoxia, hypercapnia, secondary severe pulmonary hypertension (>40 mmHg), or respirator dependency. 4. Renal: Receiving chronic dialysis. 5. Immunosuppression: The patient has received therapy that suppresses resistance to infection e.g. immuno-suppression, chemotherapy, radiation, or recent high dose steroids, or has a disease that is sufficiently advanced to suppress resistance to infection, e.g. leukemia, lymphoma, AIDS.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient meets this definition of severe organ failure or immunocompromise.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: CLINICALLY EXTREMELY VULNERABLE
Question: Clinically extremely vulnerable

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: CLINICALLY EXTREMELY VULNERABLE
Question: Solid organ transplant recipients

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: CLINICALLY EXTREMELY VULNERABLE
Question:
People with specific cancers:
• people with cancer who are undergoing active chemotherapy
• people with lung cancer who are undergoing radical radiotherapy
• people with cancers of the blood or bone marrow such as leukaemia, lymphoma or myeloma who are at any stage of treatment
• people having immunotherapy or other continuing antibody treatments for cancer
• people having other targeted cancer treatments which can affect the immune system, such as protein kinase inhibitors or PARP inhibitors
• people who have had bone marrow or stem cell transplants in the last 6 months, or who are still taking immunosuppression drugs

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: CLINICALLY EXTREMELY VULNERABLE

Section: MEDICAL HISTORY
Question: GASTROENTERITIS
Definition: This question group pertains to symptoms related to gastroenteritis.

Section: MEDICAL HISTORY
Question: Gastroenteritis illness (including diarrhoea or vomiting) in the past 3 months
Definition: Defined as an inflammatory disorder that affects the upper and lower gastrointestinal tract. Most commonly, this is attributed to viruses; however bacteria, parasites or adverse reactions can also be the culprit. Symptoms include acute diarrhea and vomiting.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this describes the type of illness the patient has reported to have experienced in three months preceding this presentation or admission.

Section: MEDICAL HISTORY
Question: Approximate start date of this illness
Definition: Please provide the date of patient reported onset of the first symptom that you clinically believe was related to this illness.
Completion Guideline: Provide the date of the first symptom that you clinically believe was related to this episode of illness in day/month/year format.

Section: MEDICAL HISTORY
Question: Did any symptoms of this illness persist for more than one week
Definition: This refers to any symptom of this gastroenteritis-like episode.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced a symptom for more than seven days.

Section: MEDICAL HISTORY
Question: Diarrhoea persisted for >1 week
Definition: Defined as three or more loose or liquid bowel movement per day (or more frequent passage than is normal for the individual).
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced diarrhoea for more than seven days.

Section: MEDICAL HISTORY
Question: Weight loss persisted for >1 week
Definition: Defined as the reduction in total body weight that has occurred since the onset of this illness persisted for more than seven days, and has been unintentional or not attributable to active dieting, exercise or dedicated medication based weight-loss interventions.. This can include patient-reported weight loss with or without objective measurements of weight.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced weight loss for more than seven days.

Section: MEDICAL HISTORY
Question: Vomiting / Nausea persisted for >1 week
Definition: Defined as either:  the unpleasant painless subjective feeling that one will imminently vomit (nausea); and/or expulsion of the contents of the stomach or small intestines through the mouth (vomiting or emesis).
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced nausea or vomiting for more than seven days.

Section: MEDICAL HISTORY
Question: Abdominal pain persisted for >1 week
Definition: Defined as an unpleasant sensation of discomfort, distress or agony in the abdominal region.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced abdominal pain for more than seven days.

Section: MEDICAL HISTORY
Question: Fever persisted for >1 week
Definition: Defined as the sensation of elevated body temperature without formal measurement, or a measured body temperature greater or equal to 38-degrees Celsius (38°C) or 100.4-Fahrenheit (100.4°F).
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced fevers for more than seven days.

Section: MEDICAL HISTORY
Question: Tiredness persisted for >1 week
Definition: Defined as the feeling of tiredness characterised by a lack of energy or motivation, also refered to as fatigue.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced tiredness for more than seven days.

Section: MEDICAL HISTORY
Question: Other symptom(s) persisted for >1 week
Definition: This refers to symptoms, other than those specified above, that occurred over 7 days.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced other symptom(s) for seven days that have not be specified above. If 'Yes', Write the other symptom(s) in the space provided below.

Section: MEDICAL HISTORY
Question: Specify other symptom(s) persisted for >1 week
Definition: This refers to symptoms, other than those specified above, that occurred over 7 days.

Section: MEDICAL HISTORY
Question: DENGUE
Definition: This question group pertains to a past history of dengue infection(s).

Section: MEDICAL HISTORY
Question: Is the patient known to have had previous dengue infection(s)
Definition: Defined as a dengue diagnosis in a clinical episode distinct from this presentation or admission.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has previously had a dengue virus infection.
Metathesaurus: CL1668488, History of dengue virus infection

Section: MEDICAL HISTORY
Question: Was the patient ever hospitalised for a previous dengue infection
Answer Options: 1, Yes, admitted to hospital or ICU | 0, No | 99, Unknown
Definition: This refers to the patient's previous history of dengue infection(s) and whether the patient was ever admitted to hospital or ICU due to the dengue infection.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes' if the patient was admitted to hospital or ICU for a dengue infection.

Section: MEDICAL HISTORY MPOX
Question: MPOX
Definition: This question group pertains to previous Mpox infection(s).

Section: MEDICAL HISTORY MPOX
Question: Was the participant ever diagnosed with mpox in the past, before this current episode of mpox?
Definition: Defined as an mpox diagnosis in a clinical episode distinct from this presentation or admission.

Section: MEDICAL HISTORY MPOX
Question: When did the previous episode of mpox begin?
Completion Guideline: Write the exact date, or if not known write an appoximate date, at which the previous mpox infection began. If only an approximate date is available Indicate is is an approximate date.

Section: MEDICAL HISTORY MPOX
Question: When did the previous episode of mpox end?
Definition: This refers to the date when the patient's lesions completely resolved and they were free of other clinical symptoms such as fever, chills, lymphadenopathy, headahce, pharyngitis, skin rashes, or other skin disturbances caused by MPXV.
Completion Guideline: Write the exact date, or if not known write an appoximate date, at which the previous mpox infection ended. If only an approximate date is available Indicate is is an approximate date.

Section: MEDICAL HISTORY MPOX
Question: Was the episode of mpox confirmed by laboratory testing?
Definition: Laboratory confirmed MPXV infection is defined by detection of unique sequences of viral DNA by real-time polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and/or sequencing (e.g. testing of a mpox lesion swab, or rectal swab).

Section: MEDICATION PREVIOUS 7-DAYS: include all taken within 7 days prior to this most recent admission / presentation
Question: Steroid
Definition: Corticosteroids (commonly referred to as ‘steroids’) refers to all types of therapeutic corticosteroid, made in the adrenal cortex (the outer part of the adrenal gland). They are also made in the laboratory. Corticosteroids have many different effects in the body, and are used to treat many different conditions. They may be used as hormone replacement, to suppress the immune system, and to treat some side effects of cancer and its treatment. Corticosteroids are also used to treat certain lymphomas and lymphoid leukaemias. Examples include: prednisolone, prednisone, methyl-prednisolone, dexamethasone, hydrocortisone, fluticasone, betametasone (note that other examples exist). Topical preparations are not included, but inhaled preparations are included.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has taken a 'steroid' in the 7 days prior to this  most recent admission / presentation

Section: MEDICATION PREVIOUS 7-DAYS: include all taken within 7 days prior to this most recent admission / presentation
Question: Steroid administration route

Section: MEDICATION PREVIOUS 7-DAYS: include all taken within 7 days prior to this most recent admission / presentation
Question: Immunosuppressant agents (not steroids)
Definition: This refers to a patient who is known to have taken prescribed medications that are known to have an immunosuppressing effect (excluding steroids/corticosteroids). Topical preparations should not be recorded.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has taken an immunosuppressant agent in the 7 days prior to this  most recent admission / presentation

Section: MEDICATION PREVIOUS 7-DAYS: include all taken within 7 days prior to this most recent admission / presentation
Question: Antibiotics
Definition: ‘Antibiotic’ refers to any agent(s) that selectively target bacteria.  Topical preparations should not be recorded.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has taken an Antibiotic in the 7 days prior to this  most recent admission / presentation

Section: MEDICATION PREVIOUS 7-DAYS: include all taken within 7 days prior to this most recent admission / presentation
Question: NSAIDs
Definition: Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs or NSAIDS refers to any agent that is not a steroid and has potential anti-inflammatory, analgesic, antipyretic and anti-platelet activities. Most nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) act by inhibiting the conversion of arachidonic acid to the precursors of prostaglandin and thromboxane by cyclooxygenase enzymes. Topical preparations should not be recorded.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has taken an NSAID in the 7 days prior to this  most recent admission / presentation

Section: MEDICATION PREVIOUS 7-DAYS: include all taken within 7 days prior to this most recent admission / presentation
Question: Antiviral
Definition: An antiviral agent refers to any agent(s) prescribed to treat or prevent viral infections by interfering with the viral replication cycle. Examples of neuraminidase inhibitors include oseltamivir, ribavirin, acyclovir and lopinavir/ritonavir (note that other examples exist). Topical preparations are not included.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has taken an antiviral in the 7 days prior to this  most recent admission / presentation

Section: MEDICATION PREVIOUS 7-DAYS: include all taken within 7 days prior to this most recent admission / presentation
Question: Antiviral start date

Section: MEDICATION PREVIOUS 7-DAYS: include all taken within 7 days prior to this most recent admission / presentation
Question: Antiviral treatment days

Section: MEDICATION PREVIOUS 7-DAYS: include all taken within 7 days prior to this most recent admission / presentation
Question: Anticoagulant
Definition: An anticoagulant refers to any agent capable of preventing blood clot formation, or platelet aggregation. This includes agents such as heparin, warfarin, aspirin, clopidogrel, and subcutaneously administered anticoagulants, among many others. Topical preparations are not included.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has taken an anticoagulant in the 7 days prior to this most recent admission / presentation.

Section: MEDICATION PREVIOUS 7-DAYS: include all taken within 7 days prior to this most recent admission / presentation
Question: Intravenous fluid
Definition: Parenteral or intravenous (IV) fluid is prescribed as a replacement of fluid, electrolytes, calories, vitamins, and other nutritional substances. Intravenous fluids may be used for rehydration, maintenance requirements or resuscitation.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes' if the patient received intravenous fluids in the 7 days prior to this  most recent admission / presentation.

Question: Indication/reason
Definition: This refers to the indication for intravenous fluids. Shock refers to circulatory failure, causing inadequate oxygen delivery to meet cellular metabolic needs. It is characterised by any two of the following: evidence of hypoperfusion (e.g. slow capillary refill, cold skin, and rapid and weak pulse), narrow pulse pressure (less than or equal to 20mmHg), hypotension for age, and tachycardia.

Question: Vaccinated for COVID-19 (ever)
Definition: Ever received a vaccine targetted against SARS-Cov-2. Examples include Spikevax (Moderna), Comirnaty (Pfizer/BioNTech), Nuvaxovid (Novavax), Vaxzevria (AstraZeneca/Oxford), Janssen COVID-19 Vaccine (Johnson & Johnson), Valneva (Valneva).
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has ever received a vaccine targetted against SARS-Cov-2

Section: VACCINATION
Question: Date of most recent COVID-19 vaccine
Completion Guideline: Write the date of the most recent COVID-19 vaccine in the format DD/MM/YYYY.

Question: Received smallpox vaccine prior to 1980?
Definition: This refers to receiving a smallpox vaccine prior to 1980 and thus unrelated to the current event.

Completion Guideline: Write the year in which the patient received the smallpox vaccine. Note it must not exceed 1980. If the year is unknown please leave this response empty.

Section: VACCINATION
Question: Completed all vaccinations under the Expanded Programme on Immunization (EPI) (BCG, Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus, Hepatitis B, Hib, PCV, OPV, MMR)
Answer Options: 1, Yes-reported | 2, Yes - confirmed with vaccination card | 3, No | 99, Unknown
Definition: This refers to the World Health Organisation Expanded Program on Immunisation.
Completion Guideline: Select the single most appropriate option corresponding to the vaccination status in relation to the EPI. Indicate 'Yes - reported' if the patient states they have received all vaccines under the EPI but do not have their vaccination card. Indicate 'Yes - confirmed with vaccination card' if the vaccination card has been reviewed and all vaccinations under the EPI have been completed. Indicate 'No' if some but not all have been completed. Indicate 'Unknown' if the vaccination status in relation to the EPI is unkown.

Section: VACCINATION
Question: Varicella vaccination
Answer Options: 1, Yes-reported | 2, Yes - confirmed with vaccination card | 3, No | 99, Unknown
Definition: Refers to varicella zoster vaccination.
Completion Guideline: Select the single most appropriate option corresponding to the vaccination status in relation to varicella vaccination. Indicate 'Yes - reported' if the patient states they have received the vaccine but do not have their vaccination card with documented evidence. Indicate 'Yes - confirmed with vaccination card' if the vaccination card has been reviewed and there is corroborating evidence. Indicate 'No' if they have not had the vaccine, or 'Unknown' if the vaccine status is unkown.

Section: VACCINATION
Question: JE vaccination
Answer Options: 1, Yes-reported | 2, Yes - confirmed with vaccination card | 3, No | 99, Unknown
Definition: Refers to Japanese encephalitis vaccination.
Completion Guideline: Select the single most appropriate option corresponding to the vaccination status in relation to Japanese encephalitis vaccination. Indicate 'Yes - reported' if the patient states they have received the vaccine but do not have their vaccination card with documented evidence. Indicate 'Yes - confirmed with vaccination card' if the vaccination card has been reviewed and there is corroborating evidence. Indicate 'No' if they have not had the vaccine, or 'Unknown' if the vaccine status is unkown.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: first data, from onset of this acute illness to day of presentation or admission
Question: Fever / chills / rigors
Definition: Defined as the sensation of elevated body temperature and associated involuntary muscle twitching/contractions (chills/rigors).
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at anytime from onset of this illness and presentation or admission.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: first data, from onset of this acute illness to day of presentation or admission
Question: Fever
Definition: Defined as the sensation of elevated body temperature without formal measurement, or a measured body temperature greater or equal to 38-degrees Celsius (38°C) or 100.4-Fahrenheit (100.4°F).
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at anytime from onset of this illness and presentation or admission.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: first data, from onset of this acute illness to day of presentation or admission
Question: Restlessness
Definition: Defined as a state of unease characterized by diffuse motor activity or motion subject to limited control, nonproductive or disorganized behavior, and subjective distress.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at anytime from onset of this illness and presentation or admission.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: first data, from onset of this acute illness to day of presentation or admission
Question: Fatigue / Malaise / Lethargy
Definition: Defined as the constellation of non-specific sensations: the feeling of tiredness characterised by a lack of energy or motivation; general discomfort or uneasiness; disinterestedness, listlessness, and indifference, resulting in difficulty performing simple tasks or concentrating.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at anytime from onset of this illness and presentation or admission.
Metathesaurus: C0015672, Fatigue | C0231218, Malaise  | C0023380 Lethargy

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: first data, from onset of this acute illness to day of presentation or admission
Question: Weight loss
Definition: Defined as the reduction in total body weight that has occurred since the onset of this illness and has been unintentional or not attributable to active dieting, exercise or dedicated medication based weight-loss interventions.. This can include patient-reported weight loss with or without objective measurements of weight.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at anytime from onset of this illness and presentation or admission.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: first data, from onset of this acute illness to day of presentation or admission
Question: Loss of smell / anosmia
Definition: This refers to patient reported and/or clinician-diagnosed inability of the patient to perceive odours
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at anytime from onset of this illness and presentation or admission.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: first data, from onset of this acute illness to day of presentation or admission
Question: Loss of taste / ageusia
Definition: This refers to patient reported and/or clinician-diagnosed loss of taste function of the tongue.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at anytime from onset of this illness and presentation or admission.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: first data, from onset of this acute illness to day of presentation or admission
Question: Clinical fluid accumulation
Definition: Refers to peripheral oedema, pleural effusion, ascites, or pericardial effusion and is detected by clinical methods, radiology, or ultrasound, without necessarily being associated with respiratory distress or hemodynamic compromise.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at anytime from onset of this illness and presentation or admission.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: first data, from onset of this acute illness to day of presentation or admission
Question: Feeling dizzy / faint
Definition: This refers to the subjective feeling of lightheadedness or dizziness which may precede an episode of syncope or a sensation of unsteadiness, spinning or rocking.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at anytime from onset of this illness and presentation or admission.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: first data, from onset of this acute illness to day of presentation or admission
Question: Cough
Answer Options: 1, Yes, non-productive | 2, Yes, productive | 3, Yes, with haemoptysis | 0, No | 99, Unknown
Definition: This refers to the presence of a cough and its characteristics. A cough is defined as a sudden, often repetitive, spasmodic contraction of the thoracic cavity, resulting in violent release of air from the lungs, and usually accompanied by a distinctive sound at the specified time. A productive cough refers to a cough accompanied by expectorated secretions (phelgm or mucus), while a non-productive cough refers to one which is not accompanied by expectorated secretions. Haemoptysis refers to the presence of blood or blood-streaked sputum from the respiratory tract.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at anytime from onset of this illness and presentation or admission.  Select the single most appropriate option that best describes the patients cough.
Metathesaurus: C0850149 Non-Productive Cough | C0451597 Productive Cough | C0019079 Hemoptysis

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: first data, from onset of this acute illness to day of presentation or admission
Question: Sore throat
Definition: Defined as an unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) and perceived to originate in the throat.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at anytime from onset of this illness and presentation or admission.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: first data, from onset of this acute illness to day of presentation or admission
Question: Catarrh
Definition: Defined as inflammation of mucous membrane with increased flow and discharge of mucose.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at anytime from onset of this illness and presentation or admission.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: first data, from onset of this acute illness to day of presentation or admission
Question: Runny nose (rhinorrhoea)
Definition: Defined as increased mucosal discharge of the nose.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at anytime from onset of this illness and presentation or admission.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: first data, from onset of this acute illness to day of presentation or admission
Question: Wheezing
Definition: Defined as a high-pitched breath sound resulting from a narrowing or obstruction of the small airway.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at anytime from onset of this illness and presentation or admission.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: first data, from onset of this acute illness to day of presentation or admission
Question: Apnoea

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: first data, from onset of this acute illness to day of presentation or admission
Question: Shortness of breath
Definition: Defined as the uncomfortable sensation of difficult or laboured breathing that is out of proportion to the patient's level of physical activity.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at anytime from onset of this illness and presentation or admission.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: first data, from onset of this acute illness to day of presentation or admission
Question: Lower chest wall indrawing
Definition: Defined as a clinical sign of respiratory distress, distinguished by the abnormal inward movement of the lower chest wall during inspiration. If only the soft tissue between the ribs or above the clavicle goes in when the patient breathes, this is not lower chest wall in-drawing.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at anytime from onset of this illness and presentation or admission.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: first data, from onset of this acute illness to day of presentation or admission
Question: Lower Respiratory Tract symptoms
Definition: This refers to the presence of symptoms from a constellation consistent with a disordered process in the lower respiratory tract. This can include: dyspnea (shortness of breath), chest pain, cough, wheezing, fever, fatigue/lethargy, among others.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at anytime during the date of assessment.
Metathesaurus: C08521254, Lower respiratroy tract signs and symptoms

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: first data, from onset of this acute illness to day of presentation or admission
Question: Pharyngitis / tonsillitis
Definition: This refers to the presence of inflammation of the throat and/or tonsils.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: first data, from onset of this acute illness to day of presentation or admission
Question: Chest pain
Definition: Defined as the unpleasant, uncomfortable or painful sensation characterised by physical discomfort localised to the chest.

Definition: Defined as inflammation of the mucosal membranes of the anus and/or rectum which can be acccompanied by pain or bleeding.

Definition: Defined as three or more loose or liquid bowel movement per day (or more frequent passage than is normal for the individual).

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: first data, from onset of this acute illness to day of presentation or admission
Question: Bleeding / Haemorrhage
Definition: Defined as the presence of blood in a location in which it is not physiologically normal or loss of blood from the circulation, either internally or externally. This can include epistaxis (blood from nose), gingival bleeding (blood from gums/gingiva), blood from any part of the gastrointestinal tract (gastrointestinal bleeding) or genitourinary tracts (vagina or urethra) including hematuria.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at anytime from onset of this illness and presentation or admission.

Question: Liver enlargement
Definition: Refers to liver englargment greater than two centimeters (2cm) below the costal margin, in relation to expected size for patients age. This may be detected on clinical examination or a radiological study.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at anytime from onset of this illness and presentation or admission.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: first data, from onset of this acute illness to day of presentation or admission
Question: Muscle aches / Myalgia

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: first data, from onset of this acute illness to day of presentation or admission
Question: Joint pain / Arthralgia
Definition: Defined as a sensation of marked discomfort in a joint.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at anytime from onset of this illness and presentation or admission.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: first data, from onset of this acute illness to day of presentation or admission
Question: Headache
Definition: Defined as the experience of pain in various parts of the head, not confined to the are of distribution of any nerve.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at anytime from onset of this illness and presentation or admission.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: first data, from onset of this acute illness to day of presentation or admission
Question: Neck stiffness
Definition: Defined as a sensation of tightness in the neck when attempting to move it, especially after a period of inactivity. Neck stiffness often involves soreness and difficulty moving the neck, especially when trying to turn the head to the side.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at anytime from onset of this illness and presentation or admission.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: first data, from onset of this acute illness to day of presentation or admission
Question: Photophobia
Definition: Refers to increased sensitivity of the eyes to light.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at anytime from onset of this illness and presentation or admission.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: first data, from onset of this acute illness to day of presentation or admission
Question: Retro-orbital pain
Definition: Defined as the experience of pain in the retro-orbital region (behind the eyes).
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at anytime from onset of this illness and presentation or admission.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: first data, from onset of this acute illness to day of presentation or admission
Question: Convulsions
Definition: Defined as an intermittent abnormality of nervous system physiology characterised by a transient occurrence of sudden, violent, irregular movement of the body, caused by involuntary contraction of muscles due to abnormal excessive or synchronous neuronal activity in the brain.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at anytime from onset of this illness and presentation or admission.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: first data, from onset of this acute illness to day of presentation or admission
Question: Seizures / Convulsions
Definition: Defined as an intermittent abnormality of nervous system physiology characterised by a transient occurrence of sudden, violent, irregular movement of the body, caused by involuntary contraction of muscles due to abnormal excessive or synchronous neuronal activity in the brain.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at anytime from onset of this illness and presentation or admission.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: first data, from onset of this acute illness to day of presentation or admission
Question: Type of seizure
Definition: Focal seizure, sometimes refered to as partial seizure. Generalised tonic clonic seizure refers to the presence of bilateral symmetric or sometimes asymmetric tonic contraction and then bilateral clonic contraction of somatic muscles, usually associated with autonomic phenomena and loss of awareness.
Completion Guideline: Select the single most appropriate option. If the seizure type is unclear or has not been witnessed Select 'Unknown'.
Standardized Term Code: 1, 29753000 | Focal onset epileptic seizure (finding) |2, 1217209006 | Generalized onset tonic-clonic epileptic seizure (finding) |

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: first data, from onset of this acute illness to day of presentation or admission
Question: Altered consciousness / confusion
Definition: Defined as a level of awareness or arousal other than the patient's normal baseline.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: first data, from onset of this acute illness to day of presentation or admission
Question: Encephalitis
Definition: Encephalitis refers to inflammation of the brain. In comparison with meningitis, in encephalitis, abnormalities in brain function are expected, including altered mental status, motor or sensory deficits, altered behaviour and personality changes, and speech or movement disorders. It is defined by an altered mental status lasting >= 24 hours along with two of the following criteria: documented fever >= 38° C (100.4°F); white blood cell count (WBC) in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) >= 5 per mm³; generalized or partial seizures not fully attributable to a preexisting seizure disorder; new onset of focal neurological findings; presence of compatible acute lesion on neuroimaging; abnormality on electroencephalography that is consistent with encephalitits and not attributable to another cause. As outlined by the 2013 International Encephalitis Consortium.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at anytime from onset of this illness and presentation or admission.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: first data, from onset of this acute illness to day of presentation or admission

Question: Specify ocular complaints
Answer Options: 1, Red eye(s) | 2, Itchy eye(s)| 3, Eye pain | 4, Visual disturbance | 88, Other | 99, Unknown
Definition: Red eye refers to any condition with dilated conjunctival or ciliary blood vessels, typical of irritation and infection. Itchy eye or ocular pruritis refers a sensation that makes a person want to scratch, in this case abnormally increased sensation of itching is in the region of the eye. Eye pain refers to an unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the eye. Visual disturbance refers to an intereference to normal eyesight without necessarily affecting visual acuity.
Standardized Term Code: 1, 703630003, Red eye| 2,  74776002, Itching of eye|3, 41652007, Pain in eye| 4,  63102001, Visual distrubance|
Metathesaurus: 1, CL473769, Red eye| 2, C0022281, Itching of eye| 3, C0151827 Eye pain| 4, C0547030, Visual distrubance|

Question: Cough
Answer Options: 1, Yes, non-productive | 2, Yes, productive | 3, Yes, with haemoptysis | 0, No | 99, Unknown
Definition: This refers to the presence of a cough and its characteristics. A cough is defined as a sudden, often repetitive, spasmodic contraction of the thoracic cavity, resulting in violent release of air from the lungs, and usually accompanied by a distinctive sound at the specified time. A productive cough refers to a cough accompanied by expectorated secretions (phelgm or mucus), while a non-productive cough refers to one which is not accompanied by expectorated secretions. Haemoptysis refers to the presence of blood or blood-streaked sputum from the respiratory tract.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at anytime during the date of assessment.
Metathesaurus: C0850149 Non-Productive Cough | C0451597 Productive Cough | C0019079 Hemoptysis

Definition: This refers to the presence of a confirmed, active sexually transmitted infection (STI). Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at anytime during the date of assessment.

Question: Bleeding / haemorrhage
Definition: Defined as the presence of blood in a location in which it is not physiologically normal or loss of blood from the circulation, either internally or externally. This can include epistaxis (blood from nose), gingival bleeding (blood from gums/gingiva), blood from any part of the gastrointestinal tract (gastrointestinal bleeding) or genitourinary tracts (vagina or urethra) including hematuria.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at anytime during the date of assessment.

Definition: Refers to liver englargment greater than two centimeters (2cm) below the costal margin, in relation to expected size for patients age. This may be detected on clinical examination or a radiological study.

Question: Headache
Definition: Defined as the experience of pain in various parts of the head, not confined to the are of distribution of any nerve.

Question: Neck stiffness
Definition: Defined as a sensation of tightness in the neck when attempting to move it, especially after a period of inactivity. Neck stiffness often involves soreness and difficulty moving the neck, especially when trying to turn the head to the side.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at anytime during the date of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment
Question: Photophobia
Definition: Refers to increased sensitivity of the eyes to light.

Question: Retro-orbital pain

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment
Question: Convulsions
Definition: Defined as an intermittent abnormality of nervous system physiology characterised by a transient occurrence of sudden, violent, irregular movement of the body, caused by involuntary contraction of muscles due to abnormal excessive or synchronous neuronal activity in the brain.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at anytime during the date of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment
Question: Seizures / Convulsions
Definition: Defined as an intermittent abnormality of nervous system physiology characterised by a transient occurrence of sudden, violent, irregular movement of the body, caused by involuntary contraction of muscles due to abnormal excessive or synchronous neuronal activity in the brain.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at anytime during the date of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment
Question: Type of seizure
Definition: Focal seizure, sometimes refered to as partial seizure. Generalised tonic clonic seizure refers to the presence of bilateral symmetric or sometimes asymmetric tonic contraction and then bilateral clonic contraction of somatic muscles, usually associated with autonomic phenomena and loss of awareness.
Completion Guideline: Select the single most appropriate option. If the seizure type is unclear or has not been witnessed Select 'Unknown'.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment
Question: Altered consciousness / confusion
Definition: Defined as a level of awareness or arousal other than the patient's normal baseline.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at anytime during the date of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment
Question: Encephalitis
Definition: Encephalitis refers to inflammation of the brain. In comparison with meningitis, in encephalitis, abnormalities in brain function are expected, including altered mental status, motor or sensory deficits, altered behaviour and personality changes, and speech or movement disorders. It is defined by an altered mental status lasting ?24 hours along with two of the following criteria: documented fever ?38° C (100.4°F); white blood cell count (WBC) in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) ? 5/mm³; generalized or partial seizures not fully attributable to a preexisting seizure disorder; new onset of focal neurological findings; presence of compatible acute lesion on neuroimaging; abnormality on electroencephalography that is consistent with encephalitits and not attributable to another cause. As outlined by the 2013 International Encephalitis Consortium.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at anytime during the date of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment
Question: Psychological disturbance
Definition: This refers to the presence of signs or symptoms that affect an individual's thoughts, emotions, behviours or mental well-being. The presence of psychological disturbances should be identfied through a Mental Status Examination (MSE) or equivalent tool.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at anytime during the date of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment
Question: Seizures
Definition: Defined as an intermittent abnormality of nervous system physiology characterised by a transient occurrence of sudden, violent, irregular movement of the body, caused by involuntary contraction of muscles due to abnormal excessive or synchronous neuronal activity in the brain. An established history of epilepsy is not required.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at anytime during the date of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment

Question: Cerebellar signs
Definition: Refers to the presence of a constellation of neurological signs typically involving coordination. Sings include: dysdiadochokinesia, dysmetria, ataxia, nystagmus, intention tremor, slurred or scanning speech, hypotonia.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at anytime during the date of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment
Question: Specify ocular complaints
Answer Options: 1, Red eye(s) | 2, Itchy eye(s)| 3, Eye pain | 4, Visual disturbance | 88, Other | 99, Unknown
Definition: Red eye refers to any condition with dilated conjunctival or ciliary blood vessels, typical of irritation and infection. Itchy eye or ocular pruritis refers a sensation that makes a person want to scratch, in this case abnormally increased sensation of itching is in the region of the eye. Eye pain refers to an unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the eye. Visual disturbance refers to an intereference to normal eyesight without necessarily affecting visual acuity.
Standardized Term Code: 1, 703630003, Red eye| 2,  74776002, Itching of eye|3, 41652007, Pain in eye| 4,  63102001, Visual distrubance|
Metathesaurus: 1, CL473769, Red eye| 2, C0022281, Itching of eye| 3, C0151827 Eye pain| 4, C0547030, Visual distrubance|

Definition: Defined as any change in the skin which affects its appearance or texture. A rash may be localized to one part of the body, or affect all the skin. Rashes may cause the skin to change color, itch, become warm, bumpy, dry, cracked, or blistered, swell and may be painful.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Enter Vital Signs data for this date?
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if you want to record vital sign data for this day of assessment. If 'Yes', for the following questions unless otherwise specified, Record the worst value (value furthest from the normal physiological range) recorded between 00:00 and 24:00 hours on day of assessment. Results that were rejected by the clinical team should not be included.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Highest temperature (select units)

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Highest temperature (C)
Definition: Refers to the highest peripheral body temperature (rectal if <3 months) in degrees Celcius (°C) between 00:00 and 24:00 on day of assessment.
Completion Guideline: Enter the highest peripheral body temperature (°C) recorded between 00:00 and 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Highest temperature (F)
Definition: Refers to the highest peripheral body temperature (rectal if <3 months) in degrees Fahrenheit (°F) between 00:00 and 24:00 on day of assessment.
Completion Guideline: Enter the highest peripheral body temperature (°F) recorded between 00:00 and 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: HR (beats/minute)
Definition: Heart rate measured in beats per minute. This may be measured manually or by electronic monitoring.
Completion Guideline: Enter the heart rate measured in beats per minute. This may be measured manually or by electronic monitoring. Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: RR (bpm)
Definition: Respiratory rate in breaths per minute. Manual rather than electronic measurement is preferred where possible (this is achieved by counting the number of breaths for one minute, counting how many times the chest rises within this time period).  If both abnormal low and high rate observed, record the abnormally high rate.
Completion Guideline: Enter the respiraotry rate measured in breaths per minute. Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment. If both abnormal low and high rate observed, record the abnormally high rate.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Systolic BP (mmHg)
Definition: This refers to the systolic blood pressure from the observation with the lowest mean arterial pressure (if mean arterial pressure has not been calculated, report the measurement with lowest systolic blood pressure).  For example, if the blood pressure is 120/85 mmHg, enter 120 in the section marked ‘systolic BP’. Use any recognised method for measuring blood pressure.
Completion Guideline: Enter the systolic blood pressure measured in millimetres of mercury (mmHg), in the relevant sections. Record the systolic blood pressure  from the observation with the lowest mean arterial pressure (MAP) (if mean arterial pressure has not been calculated, report the measurement with lowest systolic blood pressure) that occured between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Diastolic BP (mmHg)
Definition: This refers to the diastolic blood pressure from the observation with the lowest mean arterial pressure (if mean arterial pressure has not been calculated, report the measurement with lowest systolic blood pressure). For example, if the blood pressure is 120/85 mmHg, enter 85 in the section marked ‘diastolic BP’. Use any recognised method for measuring blood pressure.
Completion Guideline: Enter the diastolic blood pressure measured in millimetres of mercury (mmHg), in the relevant sections. Record the diastolic blood pressure from the observation with the lowest mean arterial pressure (MAP) (if mean arterial pressure has not been calculated, report the measurement with lowest systolic blood pressure) that occured between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Mean Arterial Blood Pressure (mmHg)
Definition: Mean arterial blood pressure (MAP) may be directly measured (via intra-arterial catheter) or be approximated without an invasive procedure using the following formula: diastolic pressure plus 1/3 of the pulse pressure, where pulse pressure is systolic pressure - diastolic pressure.
Completion Guideline: Enter the lowest recorded MAP that occured between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Lowest Oxygen saturation SpO2 (%)
Definition: This refers to the oxygen saturation, that may be measured by pulse oximetry or by arterial blood gas analysis. It is irrespective of ventilation or supplemental oxygen requirement.
Completion Guideline: Enter the percentage oxygen saturation. Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: FiO2 measured at time of lowest SpO2
Definition: This refers to the measured fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) delivered at the time of the above, lowest SpO2 (%), recording.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the FiO2 was measured along-side the lowest oxygen saturation (SpO2) reported above.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: FiO2 at time of lowest SpO2 (select units)
Definition: FiO2 can be reported as either a fraction or a percentage. Note that 0.21 and 21% are equivalent to the FiO2 of room-air.
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate units for FiO2.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: FiO2 at time of lowest SpO2 (Fraction, 0.21-1.0)
Completion Guideline: Enter the FiO2 (0.21-1.0) that was measured along-side the lowest oxygen saturation (SpO2) reported above.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: FiO2 at time of lowest SpO2 (%, 21-100)
Completion Guideline: Enter the FiO2 (21-100%) that was measured along-side the lowest oxygen saturation (SpO2) reported above.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Capillary refill time >2seconds
Definition: Capillary refill time is measured by pressing on the sternum for five seconds with a finger or thumb until the underlying skin turns white and then noting the time in seconds needed for the colour to return once the pressure is released.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the capillary refil time was greater than 2 seconds at any time between between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment. It is best performed centrally by pressing on the sternum for five seconds until the underlying skin turns white and then noting the time in seconds needed for the colour to return once the pressure is released.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: AVPU
Definition: Refers to the scoring system for consciousness: alert; responding to voice;  responding to pain; unresponsive.
Completion Guideline: Select the single option corresponding to the least responsive condition of the patient between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment. If the patient is being sedated on the day of assessment record the value before the sedation.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Glasgow Coma Score (GCS / 15)
Definition: The Glasgow Coma Scale is a scoring system for consciousness. It is scored out of 15 and requires an assessment of responsiveness to stimulus. Glasgow Coma Score: https://www.glasgowcomascale.org/downloads/GCS-Assessment-Aid-English.pdf?v=3
Completion Guideline: Enter the lowest GCS recorded. For intubated patients and patients with a non-fenestrated tracheostomy, give 1 point for the voice component and calculate the total as usual. Suffixes such as 't' for tracheostomy cannot be entered on to the database. If the patient is sedated on the day of assessment these parameters should correspond to the values observed before sedation. For daily recording, if the patient is fully sedated for the duration of the day of assessment (from 00:00 to 24:00) record 'non testable'.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Richmond Agitation-Sedation Scale (RASS)
Definition: Richmond Agitation-Sedation Scale (RASS) is a medical scale used to measure the agitation or sedation level of a person. It ranges from -5 to +4, where 0 refers to an 'Alert and calm' patient that spontaneously pays attention.
Completion Guideline: If performed, enter the lowest value (between -5 and +4) between 00:00 to 24:00 hours on day of assessment.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Severe bleeding (requiring intervention)
Definition: This refers to bleeding or haemorrhage that requires intervention. Defined as bleeding resulting in haemodynamic compromise necessitating intervention, namely transfusion. This includes World Health Organisation (WHO) Bleeding Scale grade 3 or 4.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this complication has been experienced anytime during hospitalisation.
Metathesaurus: C4023144, Bleeding requiring red cell transfusion

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: If yes, specify severe bleeding sites
Answer Options: 1, Skin | 2, Nose | 3, Gums | 4, GI tract | 5, Urinary tract | 6, Vaginal | 88, Other
Definition: This refers to the site(s) in which severe bleeding was found to originate. This can include epistaxis (blood from nose), gingival bleeding (blood from gums/gingiva), blood from any part of the gastrointestinal tract (gastrointestinal bleeding) or genitourinary tracts (vagina or urethra) including hematuria.
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate response that indicates the site(s)in which severe bleeding was found to originate during hospitalisation.
Standardized Term Code: 297968009, Bleeding skin | 249366005, Bleeding from nose | 86276007, Bleeding gums | 74474003, Gastrointestinal haemorrhage |34436003, blood in urine | 289530006, Bleeding from vagina
Metathesaurus: C0574741, Bleeding skin | C3808808, Epistaxis | C0017565, Gingival haemorrrhage | C0017181, Gastrointestinal haemorrhage |C3805433, haematuria | C0566961, Fresh bleeding from vagina

Definition: This refers to the presence of mucosal membrane involvement. It it includes the lining of the digestive tract, respiratory tract and genitourinary tract.

Question: If there are mucosal lesions: Persistant symptoms of rectitis?
Definition: This refers to a disorder characterized by inflammation of the rectum. Symptoms of rectitis include rectal pain, tenesmus, rectal bleeding, passing of mucus through the rectum.

Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient received blood products or blood product transfusion anytime between 00:00 and 24:00 hours on day of assessment. If 'Yes' Select the product(s) below.

Question: Intravenous Immunoglobulin
Definition: Examples of commercial intravenous immunoglobulin IVIG preparations include Octagam®, Intragam P®, KIOVIG®, Flebogamma 5% DIF®, Carimune NF®, Gamunex®, Gammagard S/D®, Gammagard Liquid®, Gammaked® and Privigen®.

Section: TREATMENTS & INTERVENTIONS: Record all interventions received or true between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment
Question: Plasmapheresis/Plasma Exchange
Definition: Plasmapheresis (plasma exchange) refers to the extracorporeal separation of blood components, resulting in a filtered product. Methods include discontinuous flow centrifugation, continuous flow centrifugation and plasma filtration.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient received plasmapharesis between 00:00 and 24:00 hours on the day of assessment.

Section: TREATMENTS & INTERVENTIONS: Record all interventions received or true between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment
Question: Antibiotics
Definition: ‘Antibiotic’ refers to any agent(s) that selectively target bacteria.  Topical preparations should not be recorded.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient received antibiotics between 00:00 and 24:00 hours on day of assessment

Section: TREATMENTS & INTERVENTIONS: Record all interventions received or true between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment
Question: Antivirals
Definition: Refers to any agent(s) prescribed specifically to treat a suspected or confirmed viral infection. Examples of neuraminidase inhibitors include oseltamivir, ribavirin, acyclovir and lopinavir/ritonavir (note that other examples exist). Topical preparations are not included.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if antiviral(s) were administered anytime between 00:00 and 24:00 hours on day of assessment.
Standardized Term Code: 372701006 | Substance with antiviral mechanism of action (substance) |

Section: TREATMENTS & INTERVENTIONS: Record all interventions received or true between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment
Question: Steroids
Definition: Corticosteroids (commonly referred to as ‘steroids’) refers to all types of therapeutic corticosteroid, made in the adrenal cortex (the outer part of the adrenal gland). They are also made in the laboratory. Corticosteroids have many different effects in the body, and are used to treat many different conditions. They may be used as hormone replacement, to suppress the immune system, and to treat some side effects of cancer and its treatment. Corticosteroids are also used to treat certain lymphomas and lymphoid leukaemias. Examples include: prednisolone, prednisone, methyl-prednisolone, dexamethasone, hydrocortisone, fluticasone, betametasone (note that other examples exist). Topical preparations are not included, but inhaled preparations are included.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient received 'steroids' between 00:00 and 24:00 hours on day of assessment.

Section: TREATMENTS & INTERVENTIONS: Record all interventions received or true between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment
Question: ICU/ITU/HDU/Intermediate Care Unit admission
Definition: This refers to intensive care units, intensive threapy/treatment units, critical care units, high dependency units or unit of similar level.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient was admitted to ICU/ITU/HDU etc. between 00:00 and 24:00 hours on day of assessment. If the patient has remained on a general ward (or ward not specified) between 00:00 and 24:00 hours on day of assessment Indicate 'No' or 'Unknown'.

Question: RESPIRATORY SUPPORT

Section: TREATMENTS & INTERVENTIONS: Record all interventions received or true between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment
Question: Supplemental oxygen
Definition: This refers to any method of oxygen therapy that may be delivered via nose cannula, mask or non-invasive or invasive ventilation.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient received supplemental oxygen between 00:00 and 24:00 hours on day of assessment.

Section: TREATMENTS & INTERVENTIONS: Record all interventions received or true between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment
Question: Select all types of respiratory support the patient received (from 00:00 to 24:00) on the day of assessment
Answer Options: 1, Nasal prong | 2, Face mask | 3, High-flow nasal oxygen | 4, Non-invasive respiratory support | 5, Invasive ventilation | 6, ECLS/ECMO
Definition: This refers to the mode in which the patient received supplemental oxygen on day of assessment. Non-invasive ventilation refers to the provision of ventilatory support through the patient's upper airway using a mask or similar device. Invasvie ventilation means that patient has undergone tracheal intubation, for the purpose of invasive mechanical ventilation. Invasive ventilation is a method to mechanically assist or replace spontaneous breathing in patients by use of a powered device that forces oxygenated air into the lungs. The mode of intubation may be orotracheal, nasotracheal, or via a cricothyrotomy or tracheotomy. Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation (ECMO) also called to as Extracorporeal life support (ECLS) refers to application of a life support system that circulates the blood through an oxygenating system, which may consist of a pump, a membrane oxygenator, and a heat exchanger.

Section: TREATMENTS & INTERVENTIONS: Record all interventions received or true between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment
Question: PaO2 sample type
Definition: PaO2 (partial pressure of oxygen in blood) as determined by arterial blood gas analysis.

Section: TREATMENTS & INTERVENTIONS: Record all interventions received or true between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment
Question: Type of Non-invasive respiratory support
Definition: Non-invasive respiratory support or ventilation (NIV) refers to the provision of ventilatory support through the patient's upper airway using a mask or similar device. It includes high-flow nasal cannula, continuous postive airway pressure (CPAP) and bilevel postive airway pressure (BPAP).
Completion Guideline: Select the single most appropriate option corresponding to the type of NIV used between 00:00 and 24:00 hours on day of assessment.

Section: TREATMENTS & INTERVENTIONS: Record all interventions received or true between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment
Question: Type of ECLS / ECMO
Definition: The two main types of Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation (ECMO) also called to as Extracorporeal life support (ECLS) are venous-venus, which is used to support the lungs and venous-arterial, which is used to suppor the lungs and heart.

Section: TREATMENTS & INTERVENTIONS: Record all interventions received or true between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment
Question: Prone positioning
Definition: Prone positioning refers to the act of having the patient lying in the prone position to assist ventilation. This includes both invasive ventilation/intubated patients and non-intubated or self-ventilating patients.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', for any patients if they have been in the prone position to aid their ventilation at anytime during admission. If 'Yes' Indicate what type of ventilation was occuring while prone positioning below.

Section: TREATMENTS & INTERVENTIONS: Record all interventions received or true between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment
Question: Any vasopressor/inotropic support
Definition: This refers to continous use of a vasopressor or inotrope for at least one hour. A vasopressor is a pharmaceutical agent that causes vasoconstriction. Agents include norepinephrine, epinephrine, vasopressin, terlipressin and phenylephrine. An inotrope is a pharmaceutical agent that alters the force of myocardial contractility. Commonly used ‘positive’ inotropes include dobutamine, dopamine, milrinone and adrenaline (epinephrine).
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this agent was used for at least one hour between 00:00 and 24:00 hours on day of assessment. Indicate the amount used below.
